Mary Wills is over sixty but at a time when her contemporaries are looking forward to retirement, Mary has an unpaid full time job. She is a full time carer for her frail husband and frailer mother.

Mary is the sort of person you can imagine being photographed in the local papers clutching her OBE for community service. If David Cameron's Big Society had a poster girl, it would be Mary.

Mary is indeed in the papers this week but not because her kindness and self -sacrifice has received its just rewards. Instead, Mary is locked into a frightening and expensive court battle because the government wants to deport her frail mother, Myrtle Cothill. 

Myrtle's father fought for Britain in two world wars. She has no family in South Africa and no home there any more. She cannot walk unaided and is losing her sight. 

If this were not injury enough, Mary and Myrtle have been accused of lying by the tribunal chair - although the lie he actually mentions appears to be an error of arithmetic -Myrtle's age is wrong by a year on her court statement. I suspect that this may be the chair's excuse to himself for this reprehensible decision. 

There is a change.org petition to support Myrtle. It's been very effective so far because everytime it gets another 50,000 signatures, Myrtle gets a stay in execution.

If you haven't signed this petition already, please follow the link and consider signing it.

https://www.change.org/p/the-government-ailing-92-year-old-facing-forced-removal-from-uk

I was inspired by  and his post on Gaudy Night to re-read this.

I'm very fond of the Lord Peter Wimsey series but some things about "Gaudy Night" are quite odd to the modern reader.

The book was published in 1935 and set in the same year.

Some bits of the book are timeless, Harriet is preparing to go to her old college reunion and is anxious about it . The characters in the book she's writing aren't behaving, her last relationship ended badly, Peter wants to marry her and she feels pressurised .  She's idealistic about her college and Oxford life but discovers that a mentally disturbed prankster has been sending poison pen letters to the scholars. Harriet and Peter solve the mystery and resolve their relationship.

However, other parts of the book read oddly to the modern reader. The shadow of Nazi Germany hangs over the book. Harriet has recently toured Germany , Peter keeps disappearing to put out diplomatic fires on the continent whenever Sayers wants him offstage and discussion of Nazi associated policies pervades the book.

A minor character, Miss Schuster -Sclatt is an enthusiast for eugenics and sterilising the unfit -and indeed some US states had pilot sterilisation programmes at the time-without arousing horror or disgust in any of her listeners, who seem far more exercised by her lack of tact.. The contrast between our heroine's intolerance of minor social failings and silence on major ethical issues is staggering . Harriet is clearly not in a good state and perhaps her self absorption reflects depression rather than pettiness.

It's possible that Sayers is making her views felt by putting these opinions in the mouth of an unpopular minor character . However, Peter,our hero, warmly approves of a suggestion that condemned murderers should be used for scientific experiments (as opposed to hanging) made by one of the more liberal dons -another Nazi echo . Padgett , the likeable college porter is made to remark "we need a Hitler" although it's not clear whether he means it or is subtly criticising the views of the tradesmen he's talking too, who long for the days when ladies were ladies .

The other running theme is about women's roles and the tension between marriage, motherhood and vocations. Some of this is clearly used as a plot device- Sayer camouflages  the obvious culprit in the foreground while subtly misdirecting us into a debate about celibacy and mental health .

Does the novel merely reflect the approval for Hitler and eugenics that was widespread in the UK at the time despite the Manchester Guardian reporting concerns as early as 1933( -see link to pro Hitler letters protesting against the Guardian's "unfair" coverage

http://century.guardian.co.uk/1930-1939/Story/0,,126932,00.html), is Sayers cleverly using the topical debate to increase the tension in the book or are we seeing a hint of Sayers own views ?

Either way, much though I like Peter Wimsey, I have no desire to live in the world of Gaudy Night.

by Catherine Cooked Up

It's a long time since we had a Catherine Cooked Up adventure and I'm feeling a bit stressed so here goes.

In book the first, our trusty heroine strived to fit in at Hardcastle High and defeated Aardvark, the evil MCP robot from the future.

In book the second, she discovered that all was not what it seemed in the cosy village of Hardcastle , when she discovered that her Auntie Cataclysm and that nice Mrs Sofa were really British secret agents .

 

It was 4 am and Bridget couldn't sleep. Tomorrow, Dr Sneerpout would tell them who had won the coveted Hardcastle High Science Trophy and Bridget wanted so much  to be the winner. But how could her pathetic little robot compete with the Alex H's natural gas powered car or Alex M's enormous telescope?  She'd even heard a rumour that her robot had claimed that Bridget was his science project...

 

Perhaps a little trip to the kitchen might help ? Auntie Cataclysm had been baking all week for the PTA Summer Barbecue and Sabbat . Surely she wouldn't miss a teensy weensy double chocolate muffin or ten ?  Auntie had booby-trapped the kitchen door with semtex but silly old Auntie had forgotten all about the window . In just a few minutes, Bridget had improvised a pulley and  harness from some ropes and chains that Cousin Hazard had left in her sock drawer and abseiled out of her bedroom window and was climbing in through the kitchen window.

She was just trying to make up her mind between the hazelnut and dark chocolate brownies and the muffins when she heard voices.

"Does Bridget suspect anything ?" The voice was female and seemed strangely familiar.

"i hope not" answered her Aunt. "She must never know the truth. "

"Surely she must suspect something? "

"Teenagers are very self absorbed. I don't think she's ever noticed how many twins there are in the village or wondered what happened to Uncle Cataclysm or Dr Sofa . Why should she think that we have anything to hide? "

The other woman started to laugh but was hushed by Aunt Cataclysm. The two conspirators talked on in whispers but Bridget could only make out a word here and there. If only she'd thought to bug the cottage with her Blue Peter Al Qaeda detection kit ! What an opportunity she'd lost .  Absentmindedly, she nibbled at a chocolate brownie. It was darkly delicious and had an unfamiliar spicy tang .  She reached for another and a strange hand caught her wrist !

"Mine ! " hissed Pandora . 

"Shhh !" Bridget hissed back . " Auntie will hear you!"

"Not a chance! " said Pandora coolly ,although she did lower her voice to a whisper. "Once Mum and Mrs Sofa get going about their glory days , they wouldn't notice if we danced naked on the dining room table. Anyway, if they do hear us, I'll burst into tears and say you made me do it. " She selected the largest hazelnut brownie and nibbled it.

Bridget felt a familiar prickle of irritation. Her pesky cousin was so overdue for a slapping that her palms itched with the effort of holding back.

"What glory days ?" she demanded . She didn't really care but she had to distract herself somehow.

But Pandora merely arched one eyebrow and slipped out through the kitchen window leaving a trail of brownie crumbs behind her. "Don't forget to clear up the evidence , Bridgie " she called.

"Poot" said Bridget . She knew that swearing was wrong but she had to relieve her feelings somehow until she had a few leisure moments to play Al Quaida and CIA again with the twins. She silently thanked Cousin Hazard; all those ropes and chains were jolly useful when a girl needed to make her own entertainment. Absentmindedly, she took another brownie -what was that strange spicy taste ? Maybe if she had another piece, she could work out  what it was? She drifted gently into a chocolate flavoured haze and it was only after some minutes that she realised that the voices from the sitting room were getting louder. It sounded as if Auntie and Mrs Sofa had been at the cooking armagnac again .


"Sophie, I really can't stand it any longer.  We were only supposed to be undercover for six months and we've been buried alive in this godawful hole for sixteen years. "

"Hah ! " said Mrs Sofa. "They wouldn't do this if we were men. Catch 007 or 008 doing bake sales for the PTA and baby sitting for sixteen bloody years "

"Don't talk to me about 007 , Soph. Sid I ever tell you how that nasty little pipsqueak tried to corner me in the filing cabinet at the Christmas party ?""

"Frequently, darling. Frequently" drawled Mrs Sofa.

"I swear, it it wasn't for the index linked pension, I'd be out of here tomorrow. Even Northern Ireland was better than the twins! One day I swear I'll swing for that Pandora ."

Bridget hardly knew how to contain her astonishment ! Could it really be that she actually agreed on something with Auntie ? She reached for a muffin .

"We used to be crack agents, Soph. " continued Auntie ." Remember the Cuba mission? Now the highlight of my week is spiking the PTA dinner dance punch with LSD . "

"Hey, that was good stuff! " Auntie Sofa drawled. "Little Alex synthesised it for me at home with his birthday chemistry set. "

"And that's another thing", moaned Auntie . "You get the genius scientist clones and I get the jailbait Mata Haris and that overgrown Minnie the Minx."

"You don't seem to be that badly off  " Mrs Sofa said tartly . "That field controller of yours must be clocking up the overtime. "

" I can't help it if Roger has a little crush on me " simpered Auntie . "Anyway, our romance is part of his cover."

"Oh don't make me sick!" spat Mrs Sofa ."You've been after him since he moved in.  You hussy, you! "

And the two women giggled together.

Bridget's head was spinning . She felt as if her head would explode if she heard any more. Was it all really true ? The twins clones ? Mrs Sofa a secret agent ! And that old bag Auntie having a sex life ! Ick! No! Auntie must be at least thirty !

Suddenly she felt a little sick and dizzy. Maybe she should retreat to bed with a few more brownies to keep up her strength? She reached for the plate but there were no brownies left .

"Poot" bridget said to herself. "Even Auntie's bound to notice. She let herself out of the window and crept back to her room.



Here's episode two :

Bridget felt strangely exhiliarated as she climbed back through her bedroom window. She loved adventure and Hardcastle High had seemed far too quiet after the excitement of Madame Lilian's Academy.  She chewed thoughtfully on one end of her plait and brushed brownie crumbs off her favourite stripey jumper  as she thought about what she had overheard.

Maybe if the twins were clones, they weren't her real cousins ? And who could Auntie Cataclysm have possibly been describing as an overgrown Minnie the Minx?

She bounced up and down on the bed . She was far too excited to sleep. Maybe the Alexes would be up ? She was sure they'd be pleased to see her -they were always inviting her round to play with their telescopes or look at Uranus and 4am wasn't really that late.

Soon Bridget was at Sofa Towers  and climbing into the Alexes bedroom window . For some reason, her co-ordination wasn't as good as usual and she tripped over the sill and landed on something soft  and warm. The something screamed.

"Oh hi, Alex" said Bridget breezily. "Were you asleep?"

"Bridget ? Am I dreaming ? Oh, Bridget, my sweet rubber clad ninja girl ! , how I've longed for this mo  ....ow !.."

"I'm sorry," said Bridget in a sweet mendacious tone. "did my foot slip ? "

Yesterday, we went to find the mediaeval wine cellar beneath Buda Castle for our Tokay tasting. The entrance is in the Hilton Hotel shopping mall between the Marzipan Museum (exactly what it sounds like and clearly devised by someone on far better drugs than I will ever get) and an art exhibition. There are twisty passages, there are stairs. Every so often, there is a tasteful display of grapes,bottles or posters to encourage you to venture on . There are more stairs,more twisty passages ,more bottles (empty),more grapes (plastic) .It is not clear whether we are playing Dungeons and Dragons or the Hungarian version of Mornington Crescent. 

Just as you begin to wonder if returning to the smoky sports bar of the Hilton would be a good idea, you are greeted by a strange man who seems extremely pleased to see you. After a while, you realise that this is the manager of the Faust wine bar and he is indeed extremely pleased to see you because he has been down there on his own for hours with nothing except a cellar full of wine for company. 

Hungary is full of strange grapes and grapes which sound familiar but taste completely different, such as Italian Riesling which apparently isn't Riesling and has nothing to do with Italy. 

Traditionally , Tokay is a sweet and rounded dessert wine made in the Tokay region with the Furmint grape ,but nowadays dry Tokays are made -the nearest thing is probably a very light Fino -they're fun to drink on their own and even nicer with a little goose liver pate or some ewe cheese gnocchi  . 

Faust has about 80 wines for tasting by the glass as well as palinkas , which are a local fruit brandy which remind me of Terry Pratchett's phrase about drinks which should be called "Say goodbye, Mr Brain". We managed a respectable seven Tokay tastings between us before heading back to the hotel for crispy duck with savoury strudel, but are going back to do a longer structured tasting on Saturday .

We're now halfway through our belated honeymoon and are broiling gently in the hills over Budapest. 

The weather is extreme here. When we arrived, the Danube had flooded the streets which run along the river banks (the equivalent of Victoria Embankment  in London) and the locals were out taking pictures of parking and traffic signs which only just stuck out above the water. The river buses had been grounded because their quays were underwater and the staff on the boat restaurants were enjoying an extra holiday. 

Today, it's over 34 C in town again and the river is almost back to normal . It's too hot to be a tourist except in fits and starts. In fact it's so hot that the poshest pavement cafes have got portable air conditioning units outside. The zoo has outside sprinklers for visitors to walk through to stay cool and all the locals have Gone to the Pools , which probably won't do them much good as almost all are thermal . 

The coolest place in town is the lovely cathedral of St Stephen,with it's marble walls and high vaulted ceilings. Tomorrow we plan to take refuge in the mediaeval wine cellar several stories below the Hilton Hotel where we will be forced to work our way though a Tokay tasting to justify our presence... 

Up in the hills, it's a little cooler and we have breezes to cool us down. Litres of home made lemonade and the largest ice coffees I've ever seen don't hurt either.

I've just finished reading "Cruel World" by Lynn Nicholas, an account of the treatment of children in the second world war and it's aftermath.

This is an ambitious and beautifully written book . Nicholas does not just cover the familiar ground of the mass murder of Jewish and Roma children , but also the cruel treatment of German children by the Nazi regime and the fate of stateless children after the war . It's clear from the book just how far the Nazi regime went in trying to use children as if they were state property . 

Nicholas also documents the failures of the Nazi regime to put its policies into practice and contradicts the received wisdom that the German population simply went along with whatever the Nazi regime wanted and that no one protested against the sterilisation of "defective" children or the concentration camps . 

Nicholas has also collected testimony from survivors including Hitler Youth activists, Jewish refugees and a Nazi female youth leader, who recount their experiences. 

Some of the material is familiar (at least to me) from family accounts but much is new to me and contradicts what I thought I did know.  

Nicholas has also won an award for her book "The Rape of Europa" on the fate of art treasures during and after the second world war .
